channel.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
channel.description:
well im choosing a computer and i have 2 choices dual core or quad core
[ul][li]Intel Core 2 Duo Processor E6550 (2x 2.33GHz/4MB L2 Cache/1333FSB) Intel Core 2 Duo Processor E6750 (2x 2.66GHz/4MB L2 Cache/1333FSB) Intel Core 2 Duo Processor E6850 (2x 3.0GHz/4MB L2 Cache/1333FSB) [=== Quad Core ===] Intel Core 2 Quad Processor Q6600 (4x 2.4GHz/8MB L2 Cache/1066FSB) [=== Quad Core ===] Intel Core 2 Quad Processor Q6700 (4x 2.66GHz/8MB L2 Cache/1066FSB) [=== Quad Core ===] Intel Core 2 Extreme Quad-Core Processor QX6850 (4x 3.0GHz/8MB L2 Cache/1333FSB)[/li] [li][/li][/ul]
i was thinking of the 2.4 quad core but i don't know if it would work for gaming, because i wanna play counter-strike, edit videos, play video games, and multi task. so which one should i choose quad or dual

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @brownsymcard brownsymcard
item.description:
@brownsymcard wrote:

Yes, it is true the quad is a better overclocker. However to get a 3.2 ghz oc, you should play it safe and get some extra cooling. More cores = more heat, overclock = more heat, more cores and overclock = lots of heat.

Read full topic

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @brownsymcard brownsymcard
item.description:
@brownsymcard wrote:

The quad is 2.4 ghz while the e6850 is 3.0ghz. That in itself doesn’t say much, but the essential reason is because very very very few programs even touch the 3rd and 4th core as of right now. Benchmark tests show the e6850 out performs the q6600 on all but 3d rendering programs, very recent games, and a few other side applications. Since 2 cores are unused on 99% of todays applications, the e6850 outperforms it because its 2 cores at 3ghz, not 2 at 2.4ghz.
Also a quad would require a p35 chipset, which means he would most likely need a new motherboard also which would be another $150.

Normal gaming and design/daily use; get the e6850. Crysys and professional 3d modeling; get the q6600.

Read full topic

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @S_H_A_R_K S H A R K
item.description:
@S_H_A_R_K wrote:

yah but the how does the dual outperform if the quad core is quad.

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @brownsymcard brownsymcard
item.description:
@brownsymcard wrote:

What im saying is that the quad isn’t practical yet because only a couple games and some 3d animation programs make use of the 4 cores. In the future this will change, but as of right now it is impractical to get something that will only be fully utilized once it is outdated. (ie, newer and better quads will exist by the time the majority of common games and applications will benefit greatly from a quad.)

Read full topic

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @S_H_A_R_K S H A R K
item.description:
@S_H_A_R_K wrote:

so that means theres no way of the applications only using 2 threads like the dual core

Read full topic

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @brownsymcard brownsymcard
item.description:
@brownsymcard wrote:

Yeah, but your forgetting that barely any programs make use of more than 2 cores at this time. By the time a quad core would become mainstream, and used to its potential by more than a small minority of programs.

When vista sp1 comes out, there will be far better quads than the e6600 (not to mention a larger choice in mobos that support quads), for about the same price it is now. With 99% of applications, the e6850 outperforms the e6600 due to current poor multi-threading.

It would be similar to buying an eight-core; it simply isn’t necessary or practical yet. However, if your deep into 3d modeling and animation, a quad would be the way to go.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Which processor!?!?!?!
item.dc:creator: @brownsymcard brownsymcard
item.description:
@brownsymcard wrote:

I recently had the same choice with processors. Go with the e6850. Few programs make full use of quads. If you got an q6600, by the time full potential of quads is implemented, the q6600 will be outdated.

Go for the e6850, same price, more practical for the time, less heat, less power needed, and you wont need an IP35 chipset for your mobo.

Read full topic

[quote=“The Un-Named, post:42, topic:157835”][quote author=goatee link=topic=215155.msg1882720#msg1882720 date=1195178897]

why no VISTA, all the extra features, Dx10 , halo2 MEH! my friend has it and lives with it just fine, and he has 1g ram

I don’t think there are any games that need dx10, and you can play halo 2 much better on XP. If you want more/better features, go with kubuntu or something.

Crysis need dx10. Crysis is also an amazing game!
[/quote]

Minimum System Requirements
OS Windows XP or Windows Vista
Processor 2.8 GHz or faster (XP) or 3.2 GHz or faster (Vista)
Memory 1.0 GB RAM (XP) or 1.5 GB RAM (Vista)
Video Card 256 MB
Hard Drive 12GB
Sound Card DirectX 9.0c compatible

Yet it can run on XP, so unless dx10 can be used on xp, it doesn’t use dx10.[/quote]

Its able to run DX9 or DX10 like most DX10 games…
